Message.Msg: You can't tell retail shareholders, as all the CEOs and BODs over the past 5 years have said "we are here to build shareholder value", and then disappoint them by keeping the stock at the same price while the BOD has enriched themselves with free options. If you say it, they believe you, and then you've tied up their money. Easy to say "just sell". People held and believed, and with good reason, as they saw some like Bartz take the stock up to $18, and somehow, 2 CEOs later, and a new board, we're under $15. And frankly, you don't know if all the Yahoo employees are "not complaining". If they've seen their stock go from $30 to $15 over a 5 year period, and they're not complaining, at least to themselves, they are not normal while watching GOOG and others take off. Personally, I've made money selling calls, but they haven't fetched much of a premium out of the money.
My Yahoo mail is nothing but spam -- even though that address has never been given out or used for correspondence.Go figure....
7th grade, another good one, I'm just coming down to your level to have a laugh. Why so serious???

Message.Title: YHOO to $38? don not tell BOD or Marissery-read
Message.Msg: 6 inShareYahoo! Is on Track to Reach $38 (Or More) Published: August 22, 2012 | Be the First to Comment Sebastian Bergmann Call: Buy Yahoo! Nasdaq: YHOO Contributor: Ben Michaud. Firm: H.M. Payson & Co. Type: Hedge Fund. Location: Portland, ME. Timeframe: 2 Years + Recent Price: $14.95 Target Price: $38.00 Strategy: Event/Special Situations. Disclosure: The author of this report had an active position in this security at the time of its posting. Disclaimer: This is a highly-abbreviated version of a full SumZero report republished with the author's consent. On a sum-of-the-parts basis, Yahoo! is currently worth approximately $18.67 per share – with non-core assets of $12.27 and an estimated $6.40 valuation for Yahoo! “Core”. I estimate this figure will rise to approximately $23.32 per share by mid-2015 through a combination of growth in Alibaba’s enterprise value to $55B from $35B, growth in EBITDA to $1.8B from $1.564B and annual FCF generation of ~$579MM, for an estimated 3-year IRR of ~16% per annum. Where Yahoo! becomes a highly compelling investment is through simple yet intelligent deployment of ~$18B of non-core assets over the next three years. A large-scale, multi-stage buyback program at an average price of ~$18.90 per share boosts the mid-2015 target price to $38.01 per share, for an estimated 3-year IRR of ~36% per annum – this figure only rises with tax-efficient disposal of certain non-core assets and/or a higher-than-expected terminal EV/EBITDA multiple. Such math has compelled many a hedge fund manager to take a position in Yahoo! – entrenched management, a dysfunctional Board and lack of strategic focus, however, have led to the oft-posited conclusion that Yahoo! is where hedge fund managers go to die, as Yahoo!’s perceived hidden value has thus far failed to be unlocked. The latest hedge fund manager to give it a go is Third Point – an activist, event-driven investor with a ~6% stake representing over 10% of AUM (by far its largest single-security position). Through a recent settlement with Yahoo! in order to avoid a proxy contest, Third Point received three seats on the Board (25% of total seats), two of which are occupied by restructuring experts Dan Loeb, head of Third Point, and Harry Wilson, Chairman and CEO of turnaround and restructuring boutique MAEVA Group. Since Third Point first disclosed its position in September 2011, three key overhangs – lack of strategic direction, dysfunctional Board of Directors and unsubstantiated Alibaba valuation – have been addressed, two of which were the direct result of Third Point’s involvement (the sale of half of Yahoo!’s Alibaba stake was largely independent of Third Point as far as I can tell). With the key overhangs removed, I believe the path is clear for Third Point to catalyze the series of shareholder-friendly transactions so desperately sought by prior hedge fund investors over the next three years, alongside likely operational improvements. Yahoo! announced that it is suspending its $5B buyback program designated to return the Alibaba sale proceeds to shareholders – the stock sold off considerably in the wake of the announcement upon fears of a dilutive acquisition-focused turnaround strategy. While the rumors currently flying around the tech blogosphere of Mayer wanting to make a “big splash” acquisition are relatively disconcerting, I strongly believe shareholder capital is in good hands with Third Point representation on the Board. A more likely scenario is that the Board gave Mayer the opportunity to start from scratch with all aspects of the Company, including capital allocation. Valuation Yahoo! Core trades at ~2.1X NTM EBITDA versus ~5X for AOL, its nearest comp – a multiple that fails to reflect Yahoo!’s strong cash flows, leading brand name and strong traffic base. Valuing Yahoo! Core at 5X NTM EBITDA and assuming $12.27 of non-core assets per share, Yahoo! is worth $18.67 per share today. The base-, mid- and best-case mid-2015 scenarios are $38, $45 and $67 per share. All three scenarios assume mid-2015 EBITDA of $1.8B, an Alibaba EV of $55B, accumulated free cash flow of $1.74B and a 4-stage ~$18B buyback program. Key differences between the estimated target prices include a tax-free sale of Yahoo! Japan for the mid- and best-case scenarios and a “take-out” multiple for Yahoo! Core in the best-case scenario. Click here to get more research from SumZero. Have great investment ideas of your own? Click here to enter the Value Investing Challenge and win a chance to speak at the next Value Investing Congress in NYC this October.

Message.Title: Seeking insights on a specific options strategy...
Message.Msg: Greetings: Before I ask my real question, some background for those interested in my perspective. As a technologist with 20+ years experience, I know that from technology point of view, there is hardly anything magical about what any of these companies do. I also know that if management is stupid, there is so much waste and lot of #$%$ goes around. When management is strong and knowledgeable, and has right attitude lot of #$%$ disappears. Last year, I had an opportunity to meet with Marissa Mayer at a conference and I feel she has what it takes to turn the company around. So here I am - they guy who never bought even one stock of Yahoo before, looking at options strategy. I am mildly bullish on Yahoo and believe that this baby will see $20+ price before end of the year - they need just one positive announcement. I am looking at Oct12 put spreads for net credit of $1,810.00 for example 10 contracts on each leg. Hope is that stock will rise and these will expire worthless resulting in profit of $1810. If Yahoo doesn't do well, then I loose $190 in this example! Before I take a significant trade, I thought I will check with the community. Does this make sense to anyone? Am I missing something here? LEG-1: Buy 10 YHOO Oct12 16 Put $1.34 $1,340.00 / LEG-2: Sell -10 YHOO Oct12 18 Put $3.15 ($3,150.00)

Message.Title: I HAVE AN IDEA!
Message.Msg: For years, clueless Yahoo directors, managers, employees and even the outside CPA (PricewaterhouseCoopers) have allowed a serial spamming ring to operate with impunity on Yahoo message boards. Using unlimited ID's, teaser headlines and multiple URL's, these scammers have stolen from Yahoo users and paying advertisers by offering phony stock market letters and useless advise. It has been a very profitable business run off the backs of Yahoo shareholders . Now, suddenly, the message board format has been changed to prevent these thieves from posting on the revised boards. Therefore, the spammers should use all of their ID's to post messages on the new Yahoo boards and to send complaints to Yahoo saying how bad the new format is so that Yahoo goes back to the old system that allows them to steal again. What do you think?

Probably Yang, all crap comes from him including turning down Microsofts $35 offer. No one more ignorant in the biz.

Topic.Title: Loeb must be in a coma

Message.Msg: I wish he'd get REAL. Does he really think Marissa is the answer. I hope to hell there is a plan where her pregnancy doesn't matter like a BUYOUT, otherwise I have my doubts of Loeb's competency.

Topic.Title: AAPL got 1 billion, YHOO got ZILCH!

Message.Msg: NO. The patents were violated. We had FB by the short hairs. Why do U think that FB almost immediately ran out and bought 600 million dollars worth of patents. They were scared!! YHOO screwed up with another "Bright" mgmt decision.
Agreed. BUT Mayer is NOT the answer.SELL, SELL to a more viable company. We should of had Armstrong as our CEO. Just look what he's done at AOL which I thought was a piece of crap next to YHOO.

So what exactly was the problem with the guy who was taking our share price up but he didn't have a computer science degree?????? Thompson, was it??? How many CEOs & severance packages do we have to go through before we get a $$$$ infusion in our investment???? So disappointing...

Where are people posting these days??? I've checked over on IHub but no YHOO activity there. Maybe in time interest will return to YHOO Finance board but all that is happening here currently is politics, some of which I agree with but will not rate or respond because IMO this is not the place for it. Sadly, they must not know of the multitude of sites where they can relevantly post. :( Well there is also ranting & nonsense here also but I don't want to read that garbage either...

Really, they just need to sell this company. The reason the shares are down so much since MM is because all her actions reflect one who expects to run YHOO for a while and one whom does not understand or care much about how longer term YHOO investors have only seen losses, and are anxious for a faster return and not so much for yet another turn around attempt. They need to get the value out of the YHOO holdings ASAP!

Topic.Title: AOL up almost a buck and has trippled in past year. YHOO always down and is down over....

Message.Msg: Armstrong should of been working for us, NOT AOL. Where is the thinking at YHOO. I thought Loeb was a thinker but now I wonder. These kinds of moves may prove to be too expensive. Just SELL the company.

Topic.Title: The new CEO from Google deserves a pop to $20...

Message.Msg: This should have "ALREADY" happened!!!! YHOO moves too slow and is hamstrung by INEPT mgmt. This has been the case for quite some time. I thought because Loeb had soo much at stake that things would be different now.

Scott wasn't taking the share price up much, (it was down under his tenure as well). What he needed to do was get YHOO sold ASAP or at least get Y-Jap sold and AG deal done. But, like MM, he was a kid in a candy shop, in over his head, but hoping to grow into a job he would have for a long time. And the FB suit-which may have had real merit if done sooner and properly (Thompson or YHOO did not even try to negotiate w/ FB) rather than like an ambush-was not a plus. What he needed to do was just sell YHOO! That is still the only real answer.

Topic.Title: AAPL got 1 billion, YHOO got ZILCH!

Message.Msg: oh, i get it... the patents were SO GOOD, YHOO decided to drop their case against FB?? is that what you're saying?
